description: Basic principles of chemical thermodynamics as applied to macro and nano-sized materials. This course will cover the fundamentals of classical thermodynamics as applied to the calculation and prediction of phase stability, chemical reactivity and synthesis of materials systems. The size-dependent properties of nano-sized systems will be explored through the incorporation of the thermodynamic properties of surfaces. The prediction of the phase stability of two and three component systems will be illustrated through the calculation and interpretation of phase diagrams for metallic, semiconductor, inorganic, polymeric and surfactant systems.
name: MACRO&NANO-SCALE MATLS

values.comments: This course covers the basic principles of chemical thermodynamics as they are applied to macro and nano-sized materials. The material covers the fundamentals of classical thermodynamics as applied to the calculation and prediction of phase stability, chemical reactivity, and synthesis of materials systems. The size-dependent properties of nano-sized systems are explored through the incorporation of the thermodynamic properties of surfaces. The prediction of the phase stability of two and three component systems will be illustrated through the calculation and interpretation of phase diagrams for metallic, semiconductor, inorganic, polymeric and surfactant systems.  Students generally found the material stimulating and thought that they learned a lot throughout the semester.  Professor Davies was described as someone who was “motivating” and able to stimulate interest in his students. Students also thought that Professor Davies was “honest in his criticism” and was readily available to answer any questions.  Students generally felt that this was a hard course that included very difficult exams. As a result, students spent a lot of time studying for this class. Prerequisites for this class are CHEM 101 and 102.  This review is based on the 5 student comments which were submitted.
